title: Jack Grealish seizes the chance to impress watching Gareth Southgate
text:
Compared with the demolition of Norwich City that preceded the international break, Saturday’s was a limp performance by Aston Villa, who might easily have been counting the cost of their shortcomings had Brighton kept a full complement of players.

Yet if Villa’s failure, until the very last seconds, to take advantage of Aaron Mooy’s indiscretions 10 minutes before half-time to secure three points with a 2-1 win left Dean Smith almost as frustrated as he had been with a VAR-disallowed goal, it provided Jack Grealish with the perfect platform to advertise his outstanding form.

With England manager Gareth Southgate looking on, Grealish was head and shoulders above everyone around him, which is no mean feat when you are 5ft 7in. Every piece of meaningful action had Grealish dictating its direction, culminating in the moment in stoppage time when his quick feet and inventive mind fashioned a chance almost out of nothing for Matt Targett, his partner in creativity along the left flank, to score the winning goal. Targett, who had read Grealish’s intentions, suddenly had a clear view of goal inside a heavily defended Brighton penalty area and made it count.

“Jack did a lovely bit of skill,” Targett said. “I think he’s done two people and played a lovely ball through. I was so happy it went in because it had been so frustrating in the second half.
